args.justification: ClsC_297a52fd is overloaded, grouping distinct metallurgical structures (austenitic, ferritic, martensitic) that are already represented as separate classes; splitting clarifies schema and avoids redundancy.

args.new_description: Families of stainless steels categorized by their dominant metallurgical structure: austenitic, ferritic, and martensitic.

args.new_description: Stainless steels with austenitic structure, including 300 Series types.

ClsR_423fb320 and SPLIT_Martensitic_Structure are duplicates, both representing the martensitic metallurgical structure with identical entity membership and description.

cluster_classes.class_label: Sulfide and Acid Stress Cracking Mechanisms
cluster_classes.class_description: Cracking mechanisms in metals due to sulfide and acid environments, including sulfide stress cracking and polythionic acid stress corrosion cracking.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Cracking in sulfide and acid environments.

cluster_classes.class_description: Cracking mechanisms in metals due to environmental factors, including wet H2S environments and carbon steel weldments.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Cracking in corrosive environments.

members.entity_description: Cracking of pressure vessels in environments containing wet hydrogen sulfide.

members.entity_name: environmental cracking of carbon steel weldments
members.entity_description: Cracking that occurs in carbon steel weldments due to environmental factors in corrosive environments.

cluster_classes.class_description: Cracking mechanisms in materials due to stress and corrosive environments, including stress corrosion cracking and environment assisted cracking.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Cracking due to stress and corrosive environments.

members.entity_description: A failure mechanism where cracks form in a material due to the combined effects of tensile stress and a corrosive environment.
Cracking of materials facilitated by environmental conditions.

cluster_classes.class_description: Cracking mechanisms in metals due to acid environments, including polythionic acid stress corrosion cracking.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Cracking in sulfide and acid environments.

members.entity_description: A type of corrosion that affects austenitic stainless steels and other austenitic alloys during shutdowns.

cluster_classes.class_description: Cracking mechanisms in metals caused by hydrogen and/or sulfide environments, including SOHIC, HIC, and sulfide stress cracking.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Cracking in hydrogen-exposed steel, often near welds.

members.entity_description: A type of cracking in steel caused by the presence of hydrogen and stress, often near welds, characterized by cracks aligned nearly perpendicular to stress.
Stepwise internal cracks in metal connecting hydrogen blisters, occurring without external stress.
A form of hydrogen embrittlement that occurs in metals exposed to sulfide environments.

args.new_name: Sulfide and Acid Stress Cracking Mechanisms
args.new_description: Cracking mechanisms in metals due to sulfide and acid environments, including sulfide stress cracking and polythionic acid stress corrosion cracking.
args.justification: Both classes cover acid and sulfide-induced cracking mechanisms, with overlapping scope and entity evidence (polythionic acid stress corrosion cracking and sulfide stress cracking); merging removes redundancy.
Entity 'sulfide stress cracking' fits better in the merged Sulfide and Acid Stress Cracking Mechanisms class, as it is a sulfide-induced cracking mechanism.
Assigns the correct Class_Group to the merged class for schema consistency.
Clarifies that this class covers general environmental cracking mechanisms, distinct from specific acid/sulfide/hydrogen-induced mechanisms.

args.new_name: Stress Corrosion and Environment Assisted Cracking Mechanisms
args.new_description: Cracking mechanisms in materials due to stress and corrosive environments, including stress corrosion cracking and environment assisted cracking.
args.justification: Refines the class label to better reflect the included entities and aligns with the Class_Group.

args.new_description: Cracking mechanisms in metals caused by hydrogen, including SOHIC and HIC.
args.justification: After reassigning 'sulfide stress cracking', this class is now focused on hydrogen-induced mechanisms (SOHIC, HIC); label and description updated for clarity.

executed_decisions.justification: Both classes cover acid and sulfide-induced cracking mechanisms, with overlapping scope and entity evidence (polythionic acid stress corrosion cracking and sulfide stress cracking); merging removes redundancy.
Entity 'sulfide stress cracking' fits better in the merged Sulfide and Acid Stress Cracking Mechanisms class, as it is a sulfide-induced cracking mechanism.
Assigns the correct Class_Group to the merged class for schema consistency.
Clarifies that this class covers general environmental cracking mechanisms, distinct from specific acid/sulfide/hydrogen-induced mechanisms.

executed_decisions.new_name: Stress Corrosion and Environment Assisted Cracking Mechanisms
executed_decisions.new_description: Cracking mechanisms in materials due to stress and corrosive environments, including stress corrosion cracking and environment assisted cracking.
executed_decisions.justification: Refines the class label to better reflect the included entities and aligns with the Class_Group.

executed_decisions.new_description: Cracking mechanisms in metals caused by hydrogen, including SOHIC and HIC.
executed_decisions.justification: After reassigning 'sulfide stress cracking', this class is now focused on hydrogen-induced mechanisms (SOHIC, HIC); label and description updated for clarity.

cluster_classes.class_description: Corrosion mechanisms affecting external surfaces, including corrosion under insulation and on underground or submerged systems.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Corrosion on external surfaces and beneath insulation.

members.entity_description: Corrosion occurring on the outer surfaces of underground or submerged metallic piping systems.
Corrosion that occurs beneath insulation materials, often exacerbated by trapped moisture.

cluster_classes.class_description: Corrosion mechanisms such as oxidation and sulfidation that stainless steels resist.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Stainless steels resist various forms of corrosion.

members.entity_description: A broad process that stainless steels resist due to their alloy content, encompassing various forms like oxidation and sulfidation.
A chemical reaction that stainless steels resist due to their alloy content.
A chemical reaction that stainless steels resist due to their alloy content.

cluster_classes.class_description: Corrosion mechanisms at high temperature specifically involving oxidation and sulfidation reactions.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Corrosion at high temperatures, affecting material integrity.

members.entity_description: A chemical reaction that stainless steels resist due to their alloy content.
A chemical reaction that stainless steels resist due to their alloy content.

args.new_description: Corrosion mechanisms involving oxidation and sulfidation, including high-temperature reactions and general resistance in stainless steels.
args.justification: Both classes cover oxidation and sulfidation as corrosion mechanisms, with identical entities (En_56c0bd49, En_fefc46ef) and overlapping descriptions; merging eliminates redundancy and clarifies schema.
Assigning the correct Class_Group to the merged class for schema consistency.
Confirming and standardizing Class_Group for the external corrosion mechanisms class to ensure schema connectivity.

executed_decisions.justification: Both classes cover oxidation and sulfidation as corrosion mechanisms, with identical entities (En_56c0bd49, En_fefc46ef) and overlapping descriptions; merging eliminates redundancy and clarifies schema.

cluster_classes.class_description: Corrosion mechanisms occurring at elevated temperatures, including oxidation and sulfidation, affecting material integrity.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Corrosion at high temperatures, affecting material integrity.

cluster_classes.class_description: The Heat Affected Zone (HAZ) is the region of base metal adjacent to a weld that has not melted but has experienced changes in microstructure and mechanical properties due to the heat of welding.

members.entity_description: The portion of the base metal adjacent to a weld with altered microstructure and properties due to welding heat.

cluster_classes.class_description: Corrosion mechanisms at high temperature not limited to oxidation or sulfidation.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Corrosion at high temperatures, affecting material integrity.

members.entity_description: Corrosion occurring at elevated temperatures, affecting material integrity.

args.new_description: Corrosion mechanisms occurring at elevated temperatures, including but not limited to oxidation and sulfidation, affecting material integrity.
args.justification: Both classes describe high-temperature corrosion mechanisms with overlapping descriptions and evidence, and are currently in the same class_group; merging eliminates redundancy and clarifies the schema.
Entity 'High Temperature Corrosion' fits the merged class definition and should be consolidated under the unified class.
Confirm and retain the correct Class_Group for the merged class.
Class 'Heat Affected Zone (HAZ)' is distinct from corrosion mechanisms and correctly grouped under 'Welded Joint Zones'. Confirming Class_Group.

cluster_classes.class_description: Steels designed for high temperature applications, including low alloy and quenched and tempered types.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Used for high temperature strength and creep resistance.

members.entity_description: A type of steel used for thick wall reactor vessels in petroleum refinery processes.
Steels with up to 9% chromium and other alloys for high temperature strength and creep resistance.

remarks: Class is currently coherent and well-scoped, but future review should check if 'low alloy steel' is too broad and may require splitting if more diverse members are added.

args.new_description: Steels designed for high temperature applications, including low alloy and quenched and tempered types, used for high temperature strength and creep resistance.
args.remark: Class is currently coherent and well-scoped, but future review should check if 'low alloy steel' is too broad and may require splitting if more diverse members are added.
args.justification: Class is internally consistent and already assigned to the correct Class_Group; no structural changes required, but flagging possible future need to split if 'low alloy steel' expands.
